text: Its coming up to deadline and has anyone else still not received a response from LSE? I know it says the 16th of May is the deadline, but the offer holder day is April 24th, so they should all be out before that otherwise it would be dumb to have the open day

"The assessors felt that there were strengths to your application, however admission to LSE is highly competitive and the quality of applications received this year has been high, as a result many well-qualified candidates have been unsuccessful in their application
The feedback we have received from the Admissions Selector indicates that your application was unsuccessful as a consequence of the exceptional standard of other applicants this year
LSE receives a large number of applications per place and admission to the school is highly competitive
All the information on your application has been considered holistically, and although overall your application was good, it was not as strong as other similar applicants who have applied this year."

My lnat was 21 and I thought my progression was over after being rejected by UCL but praise God!!
Looking at the modules, the LSE degree is definitely more mathematically oriented (and the degree leads with math and econ rather than the other way around.)
The LSE degree is a stem degree and provides a route into something like quant (after some grad schooling)
It also has mandatory programming courses, with the options to choose more, which is something that appeals to me (I’ve done a bit of stuff on data science)
Cambridge probably has better ‘prestige’, but a less ‘practical’ course - I mean, economic history? The social life would be far better at Cambridge (I’ve always wanted to try rowing lol)
Cost isn’t too big of a deal for me (an international applicant with UK passport, as I have a scholarship for my studies), so this isn’t that big of a factor for me
Of course, both options are great and I was very lucky to get both, but it’s a difficult choice
Got rejected because my subject combination wasn’t good enough (Maths, Further maths, Econ) even though i had the grades
Not like it's the most competitive course but I knew quite a few people who got rejected last year so I didn't get too hopeful
The weird contextual offer is kinda annoying, ABC is so random
All 4 teachers who read my PS said it is very competitive
i thought they send out offers and rejections after UCAS deadline and I got rejected so early which made me think I did something very wrong in my application
esp after my oxford rejection last friday i don’t think i hve a chance anymore smh should’ve chosen my unis better…

I firmed LSE 2 days ago and every part of me feels nauseous when I think about it :/ I’m a very extroverted person and in no way do I fit the typical ‘LSE student’ type (by that I mean, academic, highly motivated etc)
Having a good social life means a lot to me and I’m genuinely terrified that I will get there and not make any friends or have people who want to go drinking with me (superficial, I know)
Is there any way I can negate this? I.e, is it better to book intercollegiate halls to have a wider type of people around me?
Also I’m a home student so I’m worried that I won’t have anything in common with the large percentage of international students at LSE

My course is straight Politics, not sure of how many international/home students choose to do that course though I’m assuming they typically pick more ‘mathsy’ subjects rather than humanities (generalisation but this is just from what I’ve seen, don’t come at me pls).
Guys, I recently got rejected from LSE PPE on the basis of my field of study being too "narrow" (Maths, FM and Econ), and it has thrown a wrench in all my plans
Now I am unsure if I should go to one of my other uni choices (UCL or Warwick) or take a gap year and reapply for a more mathematically inclined course at LSE such as pure econ

I am afraid that PPE at either of these UCL or Warwick doesn't have the same quantatative depth required to be competitive applicant in IB, also their courses aren't as appealing as LSEs, however taking a gap year also has its drawbacks and doesn't  guarantee a place at LSE
I've received offers for LSE Finance and Imperial EFDS and an struggling to pick between the two as my firm choice
I'm torn more generally between Quant and Analyst roles which I think is the problem as I really enjoy both the coding side of finance as well as the more traditional methods of stock analysis
I'm slightly concerned about Imperials graduate prospects (which I know will be very good) compared to LSE, just because EFDS' graduate prospects are unproven
Any help and advice, whether it is on the course, location or graduate prospects, would be much appreciated
For a bit of context I have Bristol Finance as a backup with contextual grades and am waiting on UCL Stats, Econ and Finance which I understand will not be worth accepting with Imperial and LSE.

Hey, so do you think your Google search is maybe less accurate than the people who actually researched it? Since they, y'know, actually want to get in? 236th is a rubbish stat by the way- I have no idea where you got it from, but it's so obviously untrue
It's a very prestigious university, and very well ranked, at least world top 50
A simple search has gotten me #56, #37, #27, and a top ten social sciences uni in Europe

Basically internationally ranking is done based off a few indicators and the issue with LSE is it doesnt do sciences (natural sciences like bio chem etc), this means it cannot reach the top overall ranking because its a specialist institution
If you check domestic rankings which dont care about natural sciences you would see that its ranked 3rd in the country after oxbridge, above imperial etc
If you check world ranking for stuff like law, politics, IR, economics (i.e
more or less anything LSE does offer), you would see it often ranks in the top 10 in the world consistently, above top american unis like Columbia, and even Cambridge sometimes
If your studying social sciences, LSE is literally the best place in the UK to go apart from maybe Oxbridge and even then on average LSE grads earn more than oxbridge grads
If I had been accepted, I probably would have picked it over Oxford.
Its top tier and very hard to get into when it comes to Economics related fields, and may be par with Harvard etc if not better
Source: a student who dreamt to go to LSE since he was in grade 3(Sadly didn’t get in) so I have done my research.
LSE obvious has niche specialisms in which it excels at such as economics (clue in the name)
There is a bit of London bias towards it of course, but regardless it is still easily one of the best universities in the country for the subjects it offers.

I am first gen and resided from a rural area; however, my mum would always tell me to go to “LSE” (she didn’t know anything apart from its name) which she heard through a friend
I ended up at University of Waterloo for Computer Science
The library becomes your main home, your hall is your second home
The workload and standards/ exam difficulty is hectic compared to many other universities so little life/ study balance
Sadly we don’t have a completely fair ranking of some sort but US news is the better ones/popular ones out there
It’s interesting to look at how different are some of these rankings.
ironically their econ is probably the worst taught: in most cases you can't be nobel prize level researchers and teachers at the same time
So I would probably recommend somewhere else if you are looking for an academic career, but LSE is great (results wise, not for your mental health) for getting a job straight out of uni
You can usually choose up 2-3 outside options that are not related to your degree at all, exchanging academic domain knowledge for breadth e.g
take 3 of management/coding/finance/data analysis/stats modules in your history degree so it's more practical
In addition, their grading system means you can lock in a 2:1/First in either second year/third year(as long as you don't fail any third year subjects)
I.e you can get all 60s yr 1 and yr 2 and get all 3rds year 3, and still get a 2:1
(Combine this with picking easy outside options for max effect, like that 93% average Yr 1 data science course as a third year which I'm totally not doing right now)
This allows you to spend one year slacking off on uni and focus exclusively on spring weeks/return offer intern/graduate scheme hunting
Then, of course, there's the overwhelming hive mind complex of uni students that are hyperfixated on finding a grad scheme

They (especially the finance bros) will show you the good old tricks of the bullshit job app trade: i.e getting vpns to re-do the tests (or just do the test with a few other people applying to the same role, why not), faking ethnicity to meet the diversity quota, the linkedin networking etc

Just the sheer amount of peer pressure, the daily whispered conversation of he's got into X company and I've made it to the 5th round for Y company, is enough to make the laziest people apply everywhere.

I see so many of these posts, I’ll give you a rough idea of how LSE decisions work
LSE is known for taking really long, because they don’t just assess your application individually, but they also compare your application against other candidates because the places are limited
Had a buddy who told me he spoke to one of the LSE admissions ppl who came to his school to give advice
They said that the longer you wait, your chances of getting in are better
Ppl who don’t match basic requirements are filtered out first, then ppl who got lower predicted grades, then ppl w uncompetitive gcses, then they look at the quality of your ps
So, the longer they make you wait, the better your chances get
LSE is very departmentalised , so it depends on your course etc
econ is one of the most applied courses, so it takes longer to filter out ppl
I don’t want to give you false hope through this reply, but at the same time, just know, you still stand a good chance.

I’m close friends with and work with a few LSE alum, this is roughly what I’ve found:

With some of the top end unis you get additional perks that come outside the degree itself, for example it may be a good careers service, good industry links, good research opportunities, alumni benefits etc

LSE is known to have pretty strong industry and employer connections and many employers go out of their way to hold sponsored events and careers related activities at LSE, not to mention good alumni networks too

Generally the alumni network aspect is a bit lost in the UK, vs somewhere like the US where alumni networks at Ivies can really help with getting job referrals and fast track applications to roles, in this regard, I’d argue LSE is the most similar to the US with how prolific their alumni end up within Finance and Consulting
The courses themselves also are quite geared towards industry which means you develop a bit more industrial acumen by the time you’ve graduated, which can help with interviews a lot
In 2023, LSE had 26000 applicants in total, but only had 1800 places
That’s why it’s so competitive; it’s a very small university (especially relative to other London unis like UCL) whilst having a very large pool of high-achieving applicants
As for why it attracts so many applicants, it’s because of its prestige for the courses that it offers (especially social sciences), its numerous famous alumni, as well as its location in London.
They claim the median salary of mathematics graduates 15 months after graduating is £50,000
It’s difficult to comprehend why LSE has such a strong reputation, as the success of graduates isn’t as obvious for e.g Harvard
Harvard has a great reputation cos of the famous individuals that went there: gates, zuckerberg etc
However, no one is cheering for the incredible success of some dude in the finance sector who rose ranks at Morgan Stanley
You’ll find there’s a lot of those that went LSE
LSE is popular because they’re known to produce high performers in the finance sector
I've had family members who've lectured there in the past, and they've said they wouldn't send their kids there as there is apparently virtually no student support
I can't really speak beyond that as I've never seen the uni but that was enough to deter me from applying.
Didn't even know it existed tbh (guys I meant this in the past tense, I didn't know before sixth form, now I'm well acquainted).
They do, they are usually combined with a separate subject such as Economics or Statistics, as well as Data Science

Sorry but I don’t think I believe this, as it would make no sense for LSE

The reason is that LSE is a relatively small institution (offering few places) with a specific specialization in Economics, Law, and Politics, so it is really hard to combine different things in your personal statement when applying to LSE
LSE just looks at the profiles of those who have rejected them in the past, guess that they probably got into oxbridge, and uses that to determine who is most likely to reject them for oxbridge

in order to preserve their status as a top uni (and acceptance rates do factor significantly into the calculations of most rankings), they just reject these applicants, regardless of whether or not they do get into oxbridge
and the reason they take so long in their decisions is because as you said, sometimes they can’t be sure, and they’ll wait to see if that person will withdraw
someone who got into oxbridge is infinitely more likely to withdraw their application after waiting too long
that’s what being overqualified means — having the profile to get into oxbridge
low acceptance rates is due to the class size staying relatively constant and the number of applications increasing
if anything, that shows students are more willing to apply to LSE
and that’s the case too — you see people on this sub with LNAT 18 getting in, that encourages more people to apply to LSE, further pushing down those acceptance rates
nobody self-rejects from LSE the same way people do from oxbridge
it may be the best of the rest but most people certainly aren’t intimidated by the low acceptance rates.

I’ve seen the claim that LSE reject over qualified applicants swirling around on social media but I just don’t believe it as there is no evidence for it, and it would not make any sense for LSE to do it

It make no sense for LSE to reject their best applicants on the basis they think they will go to Oxbridge instead

They can’t see what other unis applicants have applied it, and even if they did, someone with perfect grades and the best PS ever written could get rejected from Oxbridge due to entrance exams or interview performance.

I would be interested to see the stats on this, but this is what I think about that
Durham is a university with an incredibly low international student population % (or diversity for that matter)
We know that universities in the UK are legally obliged to provide data that their own newspapers/magazines request (like LSE's beaver)
Theres no chance that the home students at Durham's newspapers have not requested the relevant data - and if they had found anything, they definitely would have made the entire country aware
"He has an offer from Durham whereas I don't even though I got into Imperial, which is far more competitive."
Imperial has more application steps than Durham, so they have more data points to assess you on, so its not a like for like comparison
How does that make any sense? Perfect grades, amazing personal statement and like myself, no reason given."

Durham doesn't offer an interview or require an additional assessment for economics admission, and Cambridge interviews most applicants, so those applicants were given a chance at interview despite not having the perfect personal statement/experience due to the TMUA.

So getting into Cambridge Econ, one of the most competitive Econ courses in the country, doesn't require a good personal statement? Is what you are trying to say? I don't care that I didn't get in and frankly, I genuinely had no reaction when I got rejected, but I feel sorry for those people that worked extremely, extremely hard to get amazing predicted grades, with Durham in mind as the place they want to be, only to be rejected because of some unknown generic reason

Also, if it was down to personal statement, the reason of rejection would have outright said "Personal statement was weak in comparison to other applicants" or something along those lines (the friend I am mentioning below got this reason) but a lot of people got the same "competitiveness of the course" reason

Oh for sure...I'm not denying that other people have just as impressive grades and get in but for those top-end competitive courses at Durham (looking at CS and Econ in particular),  the international to home ratio appears to be higher with the cohort being \~83% international students for Econ (my friend found this as a source directly from an FOI request, not me - don't shoot the messenger)

Also, you have to consider - what you do think is the actual number of insanely intelligent students that apply for each course at Durham that voluntarily choose not to apply to Oxbridge? I don't think that there are too many of them

I think that's the other problem - other than Maths where they accept an admissions test score (and any other course - I'm not too familiar with any other courses that accept admissions test scores), there aren't many courses that have an admissions test or an interview which I think would actually make the decision making process easier and also mean that people get a more fair decision, rather than it very much feeling like pot luck.

hi! i do english lit&lang, so these tips may not be the most helpful, but doing well in english (general) really relies on 2 things:

to figure out how to structure the argument, i really recommend examiners reports - they are by far the most slept on resource for any subject imo, but especially for english - they often include really good examples of real top mark essays, annotated by the marker! planning also really helps - i used to not plan and just go with the flow, but having 3 or 4 points plotted out with quotes and an argument really helps when you’re on a time constraint
knowing your stuff relies on hard work!! read your books

the spine of the book should be falling apart by your exams lol! annotate them and participate so much in class if you can - if you think you have a point but aren’t sure, say it! the worst thing your teacher can do is say “maybe not?” and redirect you, but at least you then don’t harbour false assumptions
- flashcards for context (DONT SKIMP CONTEXT!! A BAD POINT CAN BE MADE SO MUCB BETTER IF YOU JUSTIFY WITH CONTEXT!!)
- revision posters (e.g i have context and relationship posters for all of my books and anthology texts)
- closer to exams, plan essays; maybe even write them if you can get them marked :))
good luck!! sorry for the absolute essay this is :)

i was referring to the administration of the admissions process
firstly, UK admissions are fundamentally different since everyone has to choose a course, and the application is looked at by those who teach the course, i.e professors already on the uni’s payroll
secondly, the problem of “we had more applications than expected” could easily be avoided if they shifted deadlines forward
this year’s deadline is one week later than last year’s yet they still have to get decisions out by a certain time
thirdly, lse specifically, there was a huge chunk of time when they just didn’t get back to anybody
what were they even doing then? it looks from the outside as if all the decisions have been left to the last month or so
lastly, also lse specific but also kinda applies to other london unis, 40-50% of their applicants also apply to oxbridge
nearly half the applications they receive comes before their deadline

surely they could sieve through these first, extrapolate from previous years’ data, do determine who is likely to get an offer and keep them to benchmark later applications against while rejecting those who are very unlikely to get one
a lot of the problems above could be resolved with an earlier application deadline and some planning ahead
it doesn’t happen to US universities because they have a dedicated admissions team looking at the applicant as a person rather than an academic
to do the latter, as is the case for UK unis, you could only get the professors teaching the course to look through those applications.

But that does mean there's less if a variety of people you may meet since everyone is going into finance and that can mean there's a toxic environment, whereas at Cambridge you'll meet people who study things that aren't econ/finance

Cambridge has the bigger reputation, but LSE would let you do spring weeks and part time jobs and things, whereas I thinkkk the workload at Cambridge doesn't allow for that (tho summer internships are probably okay)
I've been told that Cambridge is more for if you want to go into research or academia, whereas LSE is more if you want to get a finance job.

so I’ve been subscribed to a few quant newsletters for a while, and all the maths they seem necessary is covered by my courses and optional modules I can take

The social life, though, would be orders of magnitude better at Cambridge and I’d probably be more intellectually stimulated and form closer friendship bonds
The way I’m currently seeing it is if I want to advance my career and make the most money (and join the rat race) LSE is the way forward
If I want to be intellectually stimulated, form close connections, and enjoy centuries worth of architecture than Cambridge is the choice
Do I sacrifice for the short term (Cambridge) or the long term (LSE)
Of course, both options are great and I was very lucky to get both, but it’s a difficult choice.
I can take being miserable in exchange for good career prospects

but I’d lose the mathematical background / market myself as STEM that would be necessary for more analytical/quant positions

I  want to give my opinion on a few of the things you said and maybe correct some misconceptions (or at least what I believe are misconceptions from my point of view)

>I’ve checked the QS ranking for math, and LSE typically in top 5 (typically behind Oxbridge and Imperial which fair enough), I have heard that the teaching isn’t that great compared to other flagship courses but I’m ok with that (having had to compensate with poor teachers for alevels)
There are two things to address here: rankings and teaching
First, any sort of rankings are largely nonsense in terms of comparing between, let's say the 4th and 7th best university - no appreciable difference

Ranking websites tend to also factor in things that are of largely no relevance to you as an undergraduate (does research output really matter to you? maybe, but certainly not more than the student experience/satisfaction), so I do not think it is very useful to use that as a comparison tool

Second, you absolutely should care about the quality of teaching! I went through my A-Levels largely teaching myself because I was going through bereavement and did not attend college much, but university is an entirely different beast (especially LSE and Cambridge)
I have had brilliant lecturers and useless ones, and the difference is night and day
The way Cambridge does seminar (tutoring?) is really conductive to learning and definitely something to consider
>No Cambridge econ student I’ve seen has been able to go into quant (which, understandable, more maths is better and there are few pure math courses there)

While this might be true, chances are that LSE Maths & Economics also probably does not yield the best results for quant offers! People doing pure mathematics, physics, and computer science will be in an advantageous position compared to you, and you will probably need to do a more quantitative master's either way
(Of note is that I am going into asset management and not quant so I am not the most informed on this, but this is my understanding from talking to my friends who are)
>The way I’m currently seeing it is if I want to advance my career and make the most money (and join the rat race) LSE is the way forward
If I want to be intellectually stimulated, form close connections, and enjoy centuries worth of architecture than Cambridge is the choice
Do I sacrifice for the short term (Cambridge) or the long term (LSE)
> I can take being miserable in exchange for good career prospects
I understand you want the best possible career prospects, but you have to question how much you are "sacrificing" compared to what you would be missing out on

If there is a decent chance of you having to do a master's either way (unless I am wrong on this of course and a joint mathematics course is enough to be competitive in quant), would you rather pick the environment that is focused primarily on competing with everyone around you to be the most employable person (which leads to a very toxic environment that seeps into societies/clubs), or one that by your own admission would be better for forming close connections and being intellectually stimulated? You probably will not have another three years of your life where you can so easily and freely meet new people from a variety of backgrounds - don't take that for granted!
With all of that being said though, I believe the most important thing that has not really been discussed is where you would prefer to live for three years
Cambridge and London are nothing alike, and will offer much different student experiences
I have been to Cambridge on a few occasions and the vibe (quaint, historical, peaceful, etc.) has felt very similar to Durham's, which I have personally really loved
If you would prefer something busier, maybe LSE is the place for you!
I have written a whole lot to avoid finishing up my summative assignment, but congratulations on your offers and hope my rambling has been at least somewhat informative

Plenty of companies almost exclusively use internships for recruiting quants, so doing an internship is a good sign that they’re happy to recruit people who did economics at Cambridge
You also don’t need to have done stochastic calculus in university to become a quant
Most of the quants I know *with maths degrees* didn’t do any stochastic calculus
A strong grasp of probability and an ability to pick up mathematical techniques quickly is much more valued in quant recruitment in my experience.

The reason I asked was how students could go into quant with such (relatively) little mathematical background in the Cambridge econ degree.
What? Real analysis is a basic first year university maths course

It might not be taught in much depth in an economics degree (where being able to use calculus is probably more useful than proving beyond doubt that an integral exists) but the basics of analysis (things like sequences and series) are not that advanced
You certainly can do postgraduate level analysis as it’s a huge mathematical field with active research going on but it’s not something which should be completely foreign to undergraduates.
First, agreed that stochastic calculus is less important than a strong grasp on Statistics

However, it still needs to be understood for asset price modelling and so on and to understand that more easily, a Maths/Physics/Engineering background would be a better platform to learn that from even if they hadn't taken electives in the specific module

I have yet to hear of or meet a quant with just undergrad Econ  -- I also tried looking for Cam Econ undergrad only on LinkedIn for quant traders and could only find like 2 or 3 people, one of which had taken modules from the Maths Tripos inc Markov Chains -- either at work (working w quants or ex-quants) or through hearsay from quant friends at top firms
If it were just about mathematical aptitude some of my own Maths/Physics peers who went to top unis wouldn't have done a MSc in Stats
You could obv argue that Econ grads are also less likely to want to become quants but..

a Maths grad from Cam (or elsewhere!) interested in quant would likely have covered at least some of applied probability (Markov chains, Brownian motion etc), time series, statistical modelling and so on..
so no need to wait for them to self-teach the prerequisites so that makes them an easier hire
At interview time, a Maths grad will have an easier time answering probability qs too
Also, idk about Cam Maths but Maths also tends to have more coding in the degree so another advantage

Literally nothing against the course - one of the smartest people I know from school who is also one of my best friends did Econ at Clare - but it doesn't go into the same depth or breadth in Probability/Statistics

Look, anything can technically happen, but it def takes more work for an Econ grad to get the same position so for OP, they might as well just do the joint degree if interested in quant positions for an easier ride

It's not like companies are handing out exceptions because someone did Econ at Cam; it's prob more the case that the people from Econ who are interning in quant firms are really just quite exceptional within their course as well (and obv Cam will have these kinds of people) and have gone above and beyond just their normal course content.

At the point that you’re choosing between economics and Cambridge and maths and economics at LSE, the important thing is going to be less the name of your degree and more the skills that you have learnt
For a quant job, either option should land you an interview
From that point on you’re being assessed on mathematical skill
Obviously a maths degree is the more useful option for helping you develop those skills, but equally it’s not impossible to do without one
The current economics students in this thread are probably a better source for how common this from Cambridge economics than I am
Ultimately, though, I’d suggest focussing slightly less on careers at this point and more on which degree you personally think sounds more interesting

It’s pretty common to end up working in a field you hadn’t even heard of before you started university, so it’s probably not helpful to choose purely based on the possibility of one specific career path
If you choose a degree that will involve learning things you find interesting, then the skills you develop will be the ones needed to get a job you find interesting
(Caveat: I’m not a quant - just know a lot of them quite well.)

I was under the impression that all they were looking for was some sort of previously achieved grade
For context, for Cambridge I had to submit an official transcript of my end of semester reports since Year 10
On the page where I had to submit that, the options were the transcript, GCSEs, or previously achieved A Level/IB results

Ultimately, if they see a discrepancy between previously achieved results and your predicted, then they have low confidence in you achieving the results that you have been predicted (As they cannot blindly trust your teachers predictions)

If you did reapply next year with your final A Level results, they wouldn't have this issue of confidence even if you did have to also submit your GCSE results as you will have already done your A Levels

Double check whether you do have to submit GCSEs even if you have already done A Levels, but even if you do, I think it would be in your interest to re-apply next year with your official A Level results.

LSE has better job opportunities but Warwick has a significantly stronger maths department so its a very fair question to ask, neither would be a bad choice
I feel like the social life here often gets a bad reputation, and not always for good reason
People typically expect to make friends with people on their course, in their department, in their societies, and in their hall of residence / accommodation

Important things to remember in regard to that is: LSE is a very international university, \~70% of the student body come from overseas, and there can be cliques of students who like to stick to their own language or cultural group, which can be off putting to others
We're also a very small university, especially with regard to the number of undergraduates, which is \~5500

The largest undergrad course is Economics, with \~220 students each year, while smaller courses like PBS, ISSP&E, FMS, or MSB might have \~20-40 students each year, which is much smaller than a larger university like Warwick, or Manchester

Careers are also a very big thing here - a lot of people put a lot of time, focus, and energy into applying for jobs, internships, work experience programmes and everything else in-between - much more so than many other universities - this can be quite alien to new students, or those who aren't career driven, especially towards roles in Finance or Professional Services

I personally hugely enjoy living in London - You are never short of things to do or see, new activities, cuisines, or areas to explore, and it is ridiculously well connected by the London Underground / buses / other TfL services, which is a huge bonus

However, living here definitely comes at increased cost - I personally pay around £1000 a month on rent and utilities for a room in a flat in East London, which is typical - When you add food costs, transport, social activities, etc, that only goes up - this is somewhat offset by an increased student loan, but it is important to recognise that cost
I think it's well worth it for what you get with the city, and the quality of education at LSE, but it's obviously not for everyone.

Tysm for the detailed answer! Another question I have is how common is it for ppl to have a job alongside studies? Is this doable given the intensity of the uni or would you not recommend?
I don't know personally that many people who have a part time job alongside their studies - I personally don't, and never have had one
I would say it is more common in your first year, when the workload is easier and when you're looking to get more experience in before Summer internship applications, kind of thing

It is more common to focus fully on your studies for second and third year, and when in your third year, you can often use savings from a summer job or Summer internship to help stabilise your income alongside your student loan.

So I did stay at uni accommodation for my first two years, but moved out for my third - it is more expensively to live privately, but I wanted something that I could rent for a whole year - living outside of halls grants you greater independence, and your own space

Breadth is always nice to have, but imo the LSE course teaches you enough to not really be lacking in any major area of Maths even within the compulsory modules
I’d love to shit on LSE being a bit stuck up vs other unis but as far as the Maths and Data Science course goes it does definitely hold its weight for its purpose

Not everyone is doing a degree to get to the frontier of research or to learn everything there is to know in 3 years, most of us are doing one to simply go further in a subject we like and potentially land a good career afterwards.

Data Structures and Algs are much easier to teach as a “Computer Science” module in first year, as you’ll see in many CS courses, often the courses are taught without the entire mathematical backing behind it, though as a CS student, learning a load of mathematical theory isn’t often a direct objective
Therefore, as a Maths module, DS/A should be taught as a module that complements what you’ve already learnt, which typically is a proper course in Mathematical Analysis and/or Abstract Algebra
If you take a look at the course contents, the Algorithms and Data Structures module requires you to have done both of those
And with your example of Warwick (my own uni), Algorithms is also a 2nd year module here too (CS260), and it’s within the CS department itself
I doubt anyone is saying Warwick’s CS or Maths department are “bad” by any means

Finally with Graph Theory, even at Warwick I wasn’t able to take it as a 2nd year option as a Maths student, the CS version exists in 2nd year but the point of that is to be a CS module, focusing on the algorithmic implications of the topic, rather than mathematical theory

I have a bunch of friends at London unis (UCL, KCL, QMUL) and the one friend I have at LSE seems to have by far the best social life
The people I know at UCL and Kings have made a few friends here and there, but they're pretty surface level friendships - they most likely wouldn't meet up outside of uni

Honestly, she's having the time of her life socially - I wouldn't fret too much about stereotypes, they're not true.
For halls I wouldn’t recommend intercollegiate, they’re not bad but they tend to not be as social, and people tend to form groups around their unis in them anyway
Passfield, Carr Saunders, Rosebery and Bankside are the most social halls with the former two having more UK students.

I’d go for Imperial, purely for the reason that you might wish to go quant eventually

It keeps all the doors open (and also opens doors to more tech side of things with data science) since the mathematical background would be a bit deeper and you’d gain more experience with coding on the course, this will massively help going into any masters course you might wish to, since they’re now almost a minimum requirement for quant at the more competitive banks

As for the job prospect side, I wouldn’t worry at all, it would be basically the same as any other similar courses offered at Imperial as well as backed by how they’re received in the job market in general, i.e
To be frank, between Imperial and LSE I’d argue that job prospects after graduation is much much more heavily leaned towards whether or not you had participated in any internships and spring weeks
An employer comparing an Imperial or LSE grad would simply choose the one with more proven experience

You can also be assured that employers aren’t going to be spending their time going around looking up the course you studied - it’s up to you to prove the value of your course, and how you made the most of it during interviews.
Go for Imperial, a degree in both coding and economics is much more valuable than the one in finance alone.

the fact that me and you have contrasting experiences and anecdotal evidences proves that there’s no fixed pattern/method to proportion the LNAT:PS
which supports my point that there’s a random order of assessing applicants and not the up-down method you’ve suggested
furthermore the PS is just a generic reason they give, so it proves literally nothing.
have you alr received your offer? & what was your lnat score if you don’t mind
haven’t seen a single person in this sub nor anyone i know irl score higher, but yea i’m supposed to believe they are doing structured holistic admissions like you mentioned
i’m just speaking from experience, as someone who received an offer last year, analysed stats and heard from staff at LSE about the process/structure of admissions, both in person and on social media
you did amazing in the LNAT, but you also need to consider it’s an arbitrary exam which isn’t standardised, so its not a make or break score, there’s no threshold
ones lnat score will never carry them, but one’s personal statement can
lse already stated that they don’t do interviews, so they use personal statements to both understand an applicant and judge whether they’re fit for the course
oxford, kcl and ucl tend to automatically deselect based on LNAT, lse doesn’t and takes a more holistic approach
best of luck though, im just trying to tell you that don’t expect a guaranteed offer because you scored 37, someone i’ve seen got rejected with a score of 39
people with scores of 24 have gotten an interview (and subsequently got in), people with 36 have been given an interview and rejected
they have a similarly, if not even more, holistic approach than LSE
having said that, i have great confidence in my application as a whole given i’m an oxbridge offer holder
you make it sound as if i feel like i’m saying i’m entitled to one
no, i’m just frustrated at how long the process is taking, and your explanation isn’t accurate at all

having said that, i struggle to see how saying it’s “holistic admissions” is anything more than a PR-boosting sort of move to encourage more internationals, who think they wouldn’t have a chance, to apply
they are only presented with 4 elements — PS, references, grades, LNAT MCQ score (and very rarely, the LNAT essay)

their idea of holistic admissions, which i’m sure you’d have also learnt by speaking to so many people, is that one strong part of an application can pull up the other weaker parts, i.e they weigh different aspects of each application differently for each applicant
the primary purpose of this is to aid weaker applicants who are borderline, and to make sure one bad day doesn’t kill one’s application

but then what if every aspect of one’s application is strong? what is the reason for rejecting someone with LNAT high 30s, excellent PS, stellar references, top grades, and excellent supercurriculars and extracurriculars mentioned in their PS? holistic admissions, according to you
going back to myself, i’ve been frustrated at how long the process is taking, but i know it takes a while and there is no ordered way in which they give out the offers
yet here you are, declaring that they are filtering through the weaker applicants already, and that all the supposedly strong ones have been chosen and given offers

hence i felt the need to say that there is no structure — if they had considered their applications in a structured manner, my application would most likely have been among the first few seen since the LNAT score is the only numerical sorting sequence, and my decision would have been out by now
unless you’re telling me that i’m a borderline LSE applicant, which, in all humility, i don’t think so

i have maxed out A Levels and GCSEs in my country’s equivalent, an LNAT score only the Top 5 each year obtains, a PS good enough to land me in oxbridge, ucl, and kcl, and excellent references from my teachers
still, i don’t think i’m entitled to an offer, but i would sure expect that my application be amongst the first to be seen and decided on, if there is a structure like you said
and i say there’s no structure because the alternative is simply yield protection — holding offers from the strongest applicants until they finally withdraw, freeing up space for the weaker ones
but yeah, because your analysis tells you that there is structured holistic admissions, you go ahead and tell it to everyone
and of course, the staff will tell you exactly what goes on in the admissions room
oh and not forgetting your experience as a reddit admissions officer
i have to be a borderline candidate it seems, according to you

not sure what more i can do though — maybe as a LSE student you could advise me on what to improve on to make my application better holistically, and how to write an 11/10 PS instead of a 9-10/10 one?

i can only speak for cambridge since I didn't apply LSE
like to be blunt those grades wouldn't be looked at as favourably if your schools average was like 6 9s
Cambridge appreciate your schooling has a huge impact on your performance so your GCSEs in context is more important than raw grades
Even with that said, Cambridge is very much biased towards tests and interviews and your GCSEs will only play a very small part, especially for subjects that you didn't pursue any further.
LSE does reject people with the reason “GCSE grades are not as competitive as other applicants”
Cambridge does not seem to focus much on GCSE’s but then it will on Alevel
In sum, LSE’s entry criteria is much more rigid and strict.
While GCSEs aren't the main focus, your A-level predictions and performance in relevant subjects matter more, a strong personal statement and LNAT/Econometrics test could help compensate for the 7.

I don’t think your gcse grades can be a reason for rejection , from what I know, most unis including LSE looks for ‘flight paths’, as in, you should be showing consistent improvement, which your predicted grades obv show
But lse econ is highly competitive, so even having almost ‘perfect’ stats does not guarantee an offer
I would say, if possible do your as levels, so you have achieved grades that show ‘improvement’ atleast for maths and further maths
I would say your ps is wayy more important than your grades but yeah, I think you should be fine

LSE specifically wants candidates to tailor their personal statement towards LSE’s course, and for it to be a full academic PS

If entry requirements are an A* and two A, and one candidate applies with an A* and two A, but another applies with 4A*, then in every scenario will the student with 4A* who is exceeding requirements be preferred than someone who just meets the entry requirements
It’s the reason why most of the people who get offers for LSE Pure Econ have 4A* or at least 3A* and 1A predicted (inc
FM), even though the their entry requirement is only 1 A* and 2 A

But every candidate who gets an offer, no matter what predicted grades they applied with, they will have to achieve the same conditions which is just the entry requirements in the actual exams to get into the uni.
That’s perfect then, as long as you expand and tell them what you learnt from each supercurricular, it’s absolutely perfect
The one thing they don’t want is someone just listing a bunch of supercurriculars and not reflecting on them at all
Since you are applying for a joint honours in Econ & Philosophy, make sure your PS is a 50/50 split between Economics and Philosophy, or close to that
A very uneven split probably won’t be favoured by LSE.

Rather than trying to decide between two universities here, I think you should be looking at the courses themselves
LSE, as you know, doesn’t offer a straight maths course
UCL is better known for maths and will offer a better course if it is specifically maths you are interested in studying
LSE is more known for the business/finance side of things and offers some interesting interdisciplinary courses which include maths
You need to ask yourself what it is you actually want to study, because the content of the two courses you’re choosing between is substantially different.
LSE for its reputation in quantitative finance and data science, but UCL isn't far behind.
Cos it is just more well known globally outside of Oxbridge
An American bulge bracket investment bank or MBB will recognize it more readily

I applied to LSE and UCL, also for PPE and got both offers back and I decided on LSE
Imo the only real benefits of UCL is that their course is 3 yrs and they may have a better social life (this isn't guaranteed though)
The courses are quite different as well as with LSE you have to do all 3 of P,P and E while at UCL you have to choose between 2 strands after 1st year
UCL also seem to have a greater emphasis on quantitative social science (Q-Step) so that might be a hindrance or benefit
The most important factor is cost, especially as an international student which means that you have to think about whether you'll get that return on investment over your career
Overall although LSE may provide a better learning quality and career opportunities, the differences between UCL and LSE aren't massive so choosing one or the other is completely justifiable
Edit: Student life is what you make of it, London in general is a large city so if you pu yourself out there then I'm sure the social life will be fine

“A BSc is the standard UK 3-year undergraduate course, which gets you a bachelors level degree
A MSci is also an undergraduate course, but it lasts an extra year

The first 3 years are identical to the BSc; in the final year, youwould typically do one big project (at least 6 months), write a few literature reviews, and be taught more advanced researchtechniques
Its not the same as a stand-alone masters degree (MSc)—which people take after graduating and lasts a whole 12 months, ratherthan just for the academic year (9 months or so)
The MSci is better preparation than the BSc for a PhD.”

On most courses, a domestic student has 4x more chance of getting in than intl student
For PPE, domestic student offer rate was 27% but intl offer rate was 5%
But it seems like more intl students get in cos the applicant pool is the whole world vs just one country
i.e., if 1000 intl students applied and offer rate was 5%, then 50 get in
If only 100 domestic students applied and offer rate was 27%, acceptance is 27

eek art is actually my weakest subject, I was borderline A grade before mocks… I would say listen to your teacher haha, and explicitly ask them what you need to be doing to achieve top grades
For example, I prefer loose, expressionistic drawing but I was told I needed to include more meticulous, detailed work to show variation and range
Hope that helps :) and good luck for your exams!
My tips for 25 markers, copy-pasted from an earlier comment I made:
Make a case for both sides but side with one off the weight of the evidence
Evaluate everything - I write a dedicated evaluation paragraph for each main point I write, but I understand that it could also be useful to integrate it as you go along
Don't get too bogged down in just discussing theory but definitely make sure it's all present
Definitely take this with a grain of salt - it's earnt me good marks in mock exams, but I haven't sat the actual A level yet

I do OCR English Literature too! I also find that it's quite light on revision - I'll memorise key quote banks (featuring multipurpose quotes from the text and from critics) before mock exams, but don't do much beyond that
Obviously there's homework, but the exams are so time pressured that it's good practice to get homework essays quickly anyway.

read the entry requirements section of this page, they say multiple 8s technically but realistically, they want 9s

[Their website](https://www.lse.ac.uk/study-at-lse/Undergraduate/degree-programmes-2024/LLB-Bachelor-of-Laws) (the one that you linked) says ‘A strong pre-16 academic profile such as several GCSE grades of A (or 7) and A* (or 8-9)
GCSE English Language and Mathematics grades should be no lower than B (or 6)
This just means that you need numerous 7-9 grades, not multiple 9s
One or two 8s or 9s might be an issue, but I highly doubt that 7 8s and 1 9 would.
The school averaged out grades with our mocks 50/50 split
We were told that they would use our mock grades 4 months after we took them
So the first set of grades was what I got in my final exam in yr11 and then after averaging it became the 2nd set.

It’s LSE though and it’s a really competitive course so realistically they’d be struggling to find differences between top notch applicants who are all capable etc etc… if they give out too many offers they get oversubscribed
It’s important to note the gcse grade profile of most successful applicants imo, things like that offer a baseline but not the full picture
This set of grades (numerous 7-9s) is hardly the minimum
OP has said that the 6 was in English language, likely the reason for rejection and not the lack of 9s
If language was actually the 5, then it’s an automatic rejection
One admissions tutor even said that you are unlikely to be rejected because of gcse grades that are seen as average in the context of applicants
888888887 would count for around average, if not, I’d say slightly higher
Also to consider that LSE likely work by having every admissions tutor see every application
They say ‘we expect’, and not ‘we require’, suggesting that a range of 9-7s is what they deem as suitable, and not the minimum
Also, LSE already use the lnat as a last indicator between two similar applicants
Why would they go to GCSE grades to see who has more 9s?
>It’s important to note the gcse grade profile of most successful applicants imo, things like that offer a baseline but not the full picture
